description: From Middle English skippen, skyppen, of North Germanic origin, ultimately from Proto-Germanic *skupjaną, perhaps related to *skeubaną (“to drive, push”), iterative *skuppōną (“to push/move repeatedly, skip”), from Proto-Indo-European *skewbʰ- (“to push, throw, shake”).

Related to Icelandic skopa (“to take a run”), Old Swedish skuppa (“to skip”), modern dialectal Swedish skopa, skimpa (“to skip, leap”), and English shove. See also dialectal English skimp (“to mock”) (Etymology 1), considered by some to be related.

entries.meaning: A leaping, jumping or skipping movement.
The act of passing over an interval from one thing to another; an omission of a part.
(music) A passage from one sound to another by more than a degree at once.
A person who attempts to disappear so as not to be found.
examples: Tracking down debtors is a big part of a skip tracer's job. That's the case because deadbeats who haven't paid their bills and have disappeared are the most common type of skips.

entries.meaning: (radio) skywave propagation

verbs.description: skip (third-person singular simple present skips, present participle skipping, simple past and past participle skipped)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To move by hopping on alternate feet.
examples: She will skip from one end of the sidewalk to the other.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To leap about lightly.
(intransitive) To skim, ricochet or bounce over a surface.
examples: The rock will skip across the pond.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To throw (something), making it skim, ricochet, or bounce over a surface.
examples: I bet I can skip this rock to the other side of the pond.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To disregard, miss or omit part of a continuation (some item or stage).
examples: My heart will skip a beat.
I will read most of the book, but skip the first chapter because the video covered it.

entries.meaning: (transitive, informal) Not to attend (some event, especially a class or a meeting).
examples: Yeah, I really should go to the quarterly meeting but I think I'm going to skip it.

entries.meaning: (transitive, informal) To leave, especially in a sudden and covert manner.
examples: a customer who skipped town without paying her hotel bill

entries.meaning: To leap lightly over.
To jump rope.
examples: The girls were skipping in the playground.

entries.meaning: (of a phonograph record) To cause the stylus to jump back to the previous loop of the record's groove, continously repeating that part of the sound, as a result of excessive scratching or wear.
(knitting, crocheting) To pass by a stitch as if it were not there, continuing with the next stitch.
(printing) To have insufficient ink transfer.

description: From Middle English skep, skeppe, from Old English sceppe, from Old Norse skeppa (“basket”).

entries.meaning: (Australia, New Zealand, Britain) A large open-topped container for waste, designed to be lifted onto the back of a truck to remove it along with its contents. (see also skep).
(mining) A transportation container in a mine, usually for ore or mullock.
(steelmaking) A skip car.
(UK, Scotland, dialect) A skep, or basket, such as a creel or a handbasket.
A wheeled basket used in cotton factories.
(sugar manufacture) A charge of syrup in the pans.
A beehive.

verbs.description: skip (third-person singular simple present skips, present participle skipping, simple past and past participle skipped)

entries.meaning: To place an item in a skip (etymology 2, sense 1).

description: Late Middle English skipper, borrowed from Middle Dutch and Middle Low German schipper (“captain”), earlier "seaman", from schip (“ship”).

entries.meaning: Short for skipper, the master or captain of a ship, or other person in authority.
(specially) The captain of a sports team.  Also, a form of address by the team to the captain.
(curling) The player who calls the shots and traditionally throws the last two rocks.
(bowls)  The captain of a bowls team, who directs the team's tactics and rolls the side's last wood, so as to be able to retrieve a difficult situation if necessary.
(Scouting, informal)  The scoutmaster of a troop of scouts (youth organization) and their form of address to him.

description: A reference to the television series Skippy the Bush Kangaroo; coined and used by Australians (particularly children) of non-British descent to counter derogatory terms aimed at them. Ultimately from etymology 1 (above).

entries.meaning: (Australia, slang) An Australian of Anglo-Celtic descent.
examples: Effie: How did you find the second, the defacto, and what nationality is she?
Effie: Is she? Gone for a skip. You little radical you.

description: 17th-century Ireland. Possibly a clipping of skip-kennel (“young lackey or assistant”). Used at Trinity College Dublin.

entries.meaning: (Trinity College, Dublin, historical) A college servant.
